awd_titl_txt: High-precision Optical Long-baseline Interferometry and Physics of Active Massive Stars
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will study B-type stars, which are much more massive than the Sun, live for relatively short time, and have disk-like features around them. These stars expel a great deal of mass to interstellar space. Thus, they are important to understanding how our Galaxy has changed over time. The researchers will use the Navy Precision Optical Interferometer (NPOI) in Arizona, which combines data from six telescopes to create highly detailed images. They will produce spatially resolved stellar surfaces and search for gaps and ring-like structures in the disks. The team will also use the nearby John Hall telescope to measure the chemical composition and physical processing occurring in the disks. Undergraduate and graduate students will participate in the research. The PI will work with Central Michigan University?s Center for Excellence in STEM Education to conduct a teacher workshop.

The NPOI facility is sensitive to the light of the hydrogen-alpha line, which is among the most prominent emission lines produced by the high temperatures associated with these disks. These data will make it possible to place strong constraints on temperature, density, total mass, and angular momentum of 35 of these stars. The time-resolved data will also make it possible to investigate the effects of any binary companions on the circumstellar disks. The PI
Will teach students data reduction techniques in an Observational Astronomy course for undergraduate and graduate students.

por.por_cntn:
The research project focused on observational study of gaseous disks around hot and massive stars.  The observational techniques utilized in this study relied on spectroscopic detection of hydrogen emission from hot disks, as well as interferometric detection of the spatial extent of the disks on the plane of the sky.  Both of these observational methods allowed placing constraints on numerical models, which in turn resulted in determination of temperature and density structures within the stellar disks. The results of this type of modeling revealed that disks around stars can be very effectively studied using this type of dual spectroscopic-interferometric approach, and combined with observations of stars with disks over a multi-year time frame allow studying processes responsible for instability of start-disk systems.  Furthermore, the computer modeling of disks revealed that it is possible to directly detect spiral structures within the disks, which arise due to the gravitational effects from binary companions.  Such an approach applied to stars with disks with extrasolar planets could be utilized to detect planets around other stars.  The results of this research have been published as peer-reviewed journal articles, as well as were in part presented at national astronomical conferences by undergraduate and graduate students that were involved in this project.

The project also allowed offering an astronomy professional development workshop for K-8 science teachers from central Michigan area that was conducted in the summer of 2018. The workshop for in-service teachers utilized the fundamental principles of observational astronomy, including modeling, guided by the research conducted on the disks of massive stars as a framework and motivation to extend these topics to classroom-ready astronomy activities for teachers. Based on the participant surveys, pre- and post-assessments, and participant interviews, it was concluded that the overall workshop was very well received by the participants, there was a measurable gain in their content knowledge in astronomy, and it appeared that the teachers were ready to utilize what they have learned during the professional development workshop in their own K-8 classrooms.
